9709/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 308, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 616, 94]]<|/det|>
The curve \(y = x^{2}\) is transformed to the curve \(y = 4(x - 3)^{2} - 8\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
Describe fully a sequence of transformations that have been combined, making clear the order in which the transformations have been applied. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 99, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 626, 102]]<|/det|>
Show that the equation \(\frac{7\tan\theta}{\cos\theta} + 12 = 0\) can be expressed as

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 107, 604, 128]]<|/det|>
\[12\sin^{2}\theta - 7\sin \theta - 12 = 0. \quad [3]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 479, 186, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 475, 636, 504]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\frac{7\tan\theta}{\cos\theta} + 12 = 0\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 479, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
The first and second terms of an arithmetic progression are \(\tan \theta\) and \(\sin \theta\) respectively, where \(0 < \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 125, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 123, 764, 144]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi\), find the exact sum of the first 40 terms of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
The first and second terms of a geometric progression are \(\tan \theta\) and \(\sin \theta\) respectively, where \(0 < \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 144, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 123, 180, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 123, 636, 141]]<|/det|>
Find the sum to infinity of the progression in terms of \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 123, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 400, 178, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 400, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\theta = \frac{1}{3}\pi\), find the sum of the first 10 terms of the progression. Give your answer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 425, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
correct to 3 significant figures. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 460, 917, 476]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 92, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 76, 917, 100]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation \(y = 2x - 8x^{\frac{1}{2}}\) has a minimum point at \(A\) and intersects the positive \(x\)-axis at \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 109, 144, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 109, 410, 128]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 98, 875, 279]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 294, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = 2x - 8x^{\frac{1}{2}}\) and the line \(AB\). It is given that the equation of \(AB\) is \(y = \frac{2x - 32}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 670, 368]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region between the curve and the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 348, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
For the greater value of \(a\), find the equation of the diameter which is perpendicular to the given tangent.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 102, 828, 203]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 223, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a symmetrical plate \(ABCDEF\). The line \(ABCD\) is straight and the length of \(BC\) is \(2\mathrm{cm}\). Each of the two sectors \(ABF\) and \(DCE\) is of radius \(r\mathrm{cm}\) and each of the angles \(ABF\) and \(DCE\) is equal to \(\frac{1}{3}\pi\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 286, 146, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 286, 364, 304]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(r = 0.4 \mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 317, 181, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 317, 468, 336]]<|/det|>
Show that the length \(EF = 2.4 \mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 317, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 504, 180, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 781, 522]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the plate. Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 79, 104, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 549, 100]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(y = (5 - 2x)^{\frac{3}{2}} + 5\) for \(x < \frac{5}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 109, 144, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 109, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
A point \(P\) is moving along the curve in such a way that the \(y\)-coordinate of point \(P\) is decreasing at 5 units per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 155, 757, 176]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which the \(x\)-coordinate of point \(P\) is increasing when \(y = 32\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 156, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Point \(A\) on the curve has \(y\)-coordinate 32. Point \(B\) on the curve is such that the gradient of the curve at \(B\) is \(-3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\). Give your answer in the form \(ax + by + c = 0\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
# Additional page
